messageBody:
Hi Scott,

moving to a Java 2 ClassLoader is the right direction.

If I understand it properly then only the test cases are
on the junit.test.path. This means only test cases
can be reloaded, but not application classes.
If this is correct then I don't see how the solution handles
the case where a fix to a test requires a change in
an application class. Since the application class
isn't reloaded the test runner needs to be restarted.

--erich

Subject
Please respond to JUnit test class reloading patch
<scottstirling@rc
n.com>








Hi,

I'd like to propose a fix for JUnit test class reloading. The proposed fix
is a Java 2 custom ClassLoader that loads test classes from its own
classpath and always delegates to the system/parent ClassLoader first
without relying on anything like excluded.properties to filter system and
non-system classes.

note: this is how Servlets, JSPs, EJBs, etc. are reloaded dynamically on
change by J2EE containers that support dynamic reloads -- the Servlet,
JSPs,
EJBs, etc. are not on the system classpath, so the system classloader can
always be delegated to and will not find the classes and this leave it to
the custom loader(s) to load them. All defined in the Java 2 ClassLoader
delegation contract.

The proposed means of configuring the custom loader's classpath is to use a
Java system property named "junit.test.path". This can be set as a command
line argument, or could be read from a properties file.

I have implemented this proposal in a small patch that can be downloaded
here:
http://users.rcn.com/scottstirling/junit-patch.jar.

A regression test (XmlTest.java) and series of steps for reproducing the
original TestCaseClassLoader bug and running the test with the patch are
here:
http://users.rcn.com/scottstirling/2003/07/19.html#a61

Thank you,
Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA
